title: Meet the newly formed Santa Ana PD Major Enforcement Team
summary:
On Jan. 6, 2020, the Santa Ana PD, flush with a 20-year high of 50 new police officers hired in 12 months last year, rolled out a new unit called the Major Enforcement Team (MET).
In addition to suppressing violent crime, the MET serves as the SAPD's primary response team for major incidents and events.
Some of the 50 SAPD officers hired in 2019 are addressing quality-of-life issues such as the homelessness crisis, Valentin said.
The MET officers look for people on parole, on drugs, or drinking in public.
The MET officers detained about 40 people who were gambling in a low-lit, smoke-choked room with purple neon lighting.

title: Santa Ana winds push through, prompting warnings throughout Southern California
authors: For City News Service In Los Angeles
The Associated Press In Los Angeles
Richard Deatley Has Been Entertainment Editor
Breaking News Reporter. He Is Currently A Business Reporter For The P-E. He Is A Cal State Long Beach Graduate
summary:
A low-pressure system pushing Santa Ana winds from the desert into Southern California will linger through Tuesday, with gusts in some areas forecast to reach 60 mph to 65 mph, the National Weather Service said Sunday.
High wind warnings were in place with warnings of difficult driving conditions for large vehicles on several roadways, including the 5 and 14 freeways in Los Angeles County.
For the Inland area, winds will hit the 15, 10, and 215 freeways and the 210 Freeway below the Cajon Pass, the NWS said.
Damaging winds can blow down large objects including trees and power lines, and power outages are expected, the NWS said.
The high wind warning was set for the Inland area Sunday evening through noon Tuesday.

I march for immigrant women who start each day working long hours while navigating language and cultural barriers.

title: Obituary: Jean O’Loughlin
summary:
Jean O’Loughlin, aged 90, passed peacefully in her sleep on March 7, 2020.
She was predeceased by her husband, Tom O’Loughlin and her brother, Bob Bonnet (Joan).
She is survived by her five children, Amy O’Loughlin (Kip Teaford), Bill O’Loughlin (Kathi), Mary O’Loughlin, Jim O’Loughlin (Solange) and John O’Loughlin (Janel Sugiyama); her eight grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren.
Jean taught school at Newport Beach for a few years until she met Tom and they started a family in Santa Ana, California.
Jean worked at home, raising kids and volunteering except for a brief stint as an interlibrary loan specialist at the Santa Ana Public Library.

title: Police Kill Suspected Shooter After Taking Fire Inside Santa Ana Church
summary:
A suspected shooter was killed Sunday after firing at officers inside an Orange County church, Santa Ana police said.
Police responded to a report of fighting in the parking lot of Merchant Logo Immaculate Heart of Mary Catholic Church, located at 1100 S. Center St. in Santa Ana around 4:15 p.m., the Santa Ana Police Department said in a press release.
The shooting took place inside the church, near the altar, with the suspect running outside and found dead with a firearm outside the church, Santa Ana Police Chief David Valentin said.
The shooting took place in between mass, with 10-15 people inside the church, Valentin said.
A voting center inside the church was closed indefinitely due to the shooting, according to the Orange County Registrar of Voters.

summary:
He becomes the newest member of the Santa Ana Measure X Citizen Oversight Committee.
Perea, 28, is the first Santa Ana resident without legal immigration status to be appointed to a city advisory committee, according to city officials.
In Santa Ana, a predominantly Latino city, existing citizen advisory boards – except a youth commission – require applicants to be registered voters, who by default would have to be citizens.
Councilman Vicente Sarmiento appointed Perea.
He praised Santa Ana for eliminating the citizenship requirement to serve on the Measure X committee, saying “Santa Ana continues to lead in uplifting immigrant rights in Orange County by removing barriers to participation in their local government.”Perea moved to Santa Ana in 2006, after crossing illegally into the country to reunite with his mother.

title: How Climate Change Could Shift California’s Santa Ana Winds, Fueling Fires
summary:
For centuries, humans have experienced the fierce, hot and dry winds that are fanning California’s recent spate of wildfires.
Known as Santa Anas in the southern part of the state and Diablos in the north, they arrive regularly in the fall.
“They’ve been here since before we’ve been here,” said Janin Guzman-Morales, a postdoctoral researcher at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography at the University of California, San Diego.
“It’s a natural process in this region.”But the winds’ future in a changing climate is less certain.
Recent research by Dr. Guzman-Morales and others suggests that as the climate warms, the winds may become less frequent, especially at the fringes of their season in fall and spring.

title: John Wayne Flyer Numbers Fall
summary:
SANTA ANA, CA – Data released by John Wayne Airport today showed an overall decrease in numbers for November 2019 when compared with November 2018.
As a whole, total aircraft operations (flight take-offs and landings) were down almost 16 percent compared to November 2018.
The number of individual international passenger transactions was down 30 percent whilst international flight operations fell 35 percent.
The figures are not all doom and gloom however, as both the numbers of commuter flights and military flight both showed strong increases, with military operations rising more than 60 percent and commuter operations more than doubling.
Similarly, although air cargo and total aircraft operations are down over 2018, their year-to-date losses are only in single figures : air cargo falling 9 percent and total operations off 4 percent.

title: City of Ventura settles lawsuit, agrees to turn over records related to Thomas Fire
summary:
The city of Ventura has agreed to turn over records to county Supervisor Steve Bennett, who sued for their release after failing to get answers on how critical infrastructure fared during the Thomas Fire.
In the settlement with Bennett, the city said it had 82 documents responsive to Bennett's public records request from March 25, 2019, that had not yet been released.
It agreed to release all the records, except for two documents it said were prepared specifically for litigation, an exemption under state public records law.
"I'm glad we're finally getting the public information that we had a legal right to get two years ago," Bennett said Monday.
The city initially withheld records, citing exemptions in state public records law that include pending litigation, attorney-client privilege and that the public interest was better served by keeping them private.

However, experts caution the blaze may be a preview of what could be a long season of devastating fires amid gusty winds and dry conditions.
A report from the National Interagency Fire Center, released Friday, predicts a higher-than-normal chance for other large fires in Southern California through December, with a late start to the rainy season looking increasingly likely.
However, Southern California hasn’t had significant rain in seven months, and meteorologists say there’s no clear sign of rain anywhere in the forecast through at least mid-November.

title: How Climate Change Could Shift California’s Santa Ana Winds, Fueling Fires
summary:
For centuries, humans have experienced the fierce, hot and dry winds that are fanning California’s recent spate of wildfires.
Known as Santa Anas in the southern part of the state and Diablos in the north, they arrive regularly in the fall.
“They’ve been here since before we’ve been here,” said Janin Guzman-Morales, a postdoctoral researcher at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography at the University of California, San Diego.
“It’s a natural process in this region.”But the winds’ future in a changing climate is less certain.
Recent research by Dr. Guzman-Morales and others suggests that as the climate warms, the winds may become less frequent, especially at the fringes of their season in fall and spring.
